fields.summary: Not possible to scroll horizontally in diff viewer
"Finish feature" button text  in git flow dialog should contain ellipsis

fields.description:
Would be possible to mark branches in list of branches and under remotes on left side of ST main window somehow with same color they are represented in graph in Log/History window?
 I'm thinking about something like dots in proper colors, see attached screenshot.
  
 The thing is, when I'm looking to history and the "last commit in branch" markers are not visible, I don't know which branch is which in Log/History window... And when you have more then 2-3 branches, I personally am lost...
fields.summary: Coloring branches in list of branches

fields.description:
In versions prior to 2.0, the overview of repositories allowed me to quickly navigate my repositories, but now I have this big tabsheet and I'm lost all the time:

!RepoBar.png!

I don't need all of these projects all of the time. There are a handful that I work on on a near daily basis, and others that I just need to check periodically to fix an issue, review a change, or just pull something for a dependency. 

Example solutions that would help me:
 * Some list or tree of projects that could (optionally) be docked, and could be shown and hidden easily using a shortcut.
 The current "local repositories" view would do, if there was a shortcut that takes me to it's search box right away, but so far I haven't been able to find it. 
 If there is already a shortcut for this, maybe that needs to be visible somewhere in the menu or in a hint on the tabs + button. 
 Also note that repeated clicks on '+' would repeatedly open new tabs, even if you didn't open a repository. Maybe you should go to the same tab if you use that shortcut.
 * Possibility to 'pin' repository tabs and a popup menu item to close unpinned projects. That way I could pin the dozen most used projects and easily clean my tab sheets.
fields.summary: Easier overview of and access to large list of repositories
UI Issue

fields.description:
Hello,

 

gitflow hotfix always merges master into develop, is this the expected behaviour?

This is not the way how it works in earlier release.
fields.summary: Gitflow hotfix automatically merges master into develop

fields.description:
Everytime I start Source Tree, my .gitconfig file is overwritten, which leads to me not being able to access my repositories due to missing proxy server entries in the .gitconfig.

This appears to be a bug, as Brian Ganninger confirmed in reply to my question:

[https://community.atlassian.com/t5/Sourcetree-questions/How-can-I-prevent-Sourcetree-from-overwriting-my-gitconfig/qaq-p/757138]

Unfortunately, the following thread did not solve the problem, because the setting "Allow SourceTree to modify my global Git and Mercurial config files" is reset to "true" everytime I start Sourcetree.

[https://community.atlassian.com/t5/Sourcetree-questions/Why-does-SourceTree-automatically-update-my-gitconfig-file/qaq-p/414282]
fields.summary: Sourcetree overwrites .gitconfig without permission

fields.description:
The bug prevents me from using any external diff tool.

Open C:\Users\...\.gitconfig

Change the paths to diff tools to something containing spaces (like C:/Program Files), in quotes.

Open SourceTree.

After opening SourceTree, new corrupted entries will show up in .gitconfig file (the "C:/Program" line).
{code:java}
[difftool "sourcetree"]
 cmd = 'C:/Program Files/Perforce/p4merge.exe' $LOCAL $REMOTE
 cmd = 'C:/Program
[mergetool "sourcetree"]
 cmd = 'C:/Program Files/Perforce/p4merge.exe' $BASE $LOCAL $REMOTE
 trustExitCode = true
 cmd = 'C:/Program
{code}
fields.summary: SourceTree corrupts .gitconfig's merge tool entries

fields.description:
The first screenshot was made in the display mode of the date order. [http://take.ms/LSDgN]

It can be seen that the commit 0248a2b goes away and breaks off. Although his ancestor is located higher on 1 commit. Its correct location is indicated by a purple arrow.

In the sorting by ancestor order, the display is correct. [http://take.ms/Sf7H8]

Probably this is due to the same dates (17:11) for the two commits and it's necessary to use ancestors when sorting by dates, i.e. at coincidence of dates - to consider the ancestor.

fields.summary: User details associated with commits won't accept email address

fields.description:
I use pageant on windows to authenticate Bitbucket SSH connection.

Occasionally I forget to load my SSH key into pageant and then Sourcetree pops up an authenticate dialogue requesting password. But there is no password. Even after pageant has then been loaded, this popup persists.

BUG: I have not found out how to get rid of this popup (without rebooting), which returns  the moment you close it, even after Sourcetree has been terminated.
fields.summary: Authenticate  login popup persists

fields.description:
I had SourceTree installed with configuration set to use system Git. After updating Git from 2.16.2 to 2.17.0-RC0 SourceTree no longer finds the installed Git version.

On startup it complains that no Git was found and gives me some options. If I click the button to browse for the Git path, nothing happens and the same dialog appears again.

 

git.exe is in the path and everything works fine on the command line and in other clients.
fields.summary: System Git no longer found after update to 2.17.0-RC0

fields.description:
I don't know where SourceTree keeps "Commit text links" settings but I keep losing them from time to time.
It would be the best would it stored those in git config so that those can we automatically configured.
fields.summary: Save commit links in .git config

fields.description: I keep getting an authorisation fail message when trying to Clone a repository set up in Bitbucket. I have tried resetting the password, downloading a newer version of sourcetree (version 2.4.8.0) and restarting the computer with no luck.

fields.summary: Unable to install SourceTree

fields.description:
Currently, during rebase conflict resolution, it is a bit of a discovery/usability issue that one has to proceed by finding submenu items that are available only under the Actions menu, and only during a rebase that has a conflict.  Rebase may result in a conflict, from which the appropriate action is usually to 'continue' or sometimes to 'skip' depending on whether the conflict resolution resulted in nullifying the commit (in my opinion, continue should just do both..).  This is a different situation from a merge, as merging is a single step operation, so one can simply commit the merge commit after resolving any conflict.  Based on the merge pattern, one might guess to try either the merge button or the commit button, but both are problematic, because commit then confusingly tells you to write a commit message which is meaningless in a conflict resolution context, and merge is probably not something you'd want to do as merging during a rebase is a recipe for massive confusion (I recommend disabling the merge button during a merge or rebase to help tell the user that they're in one already... and perhaps disabling the commit button during a rebase). I think that having the most appropriate action hidden under the Actions menu is a usability issue, and my suggestion for improving usability would be to either replace the Merge button with a highlighted Continue Rebase button, or have a new button in the same the same menu bar that only exists during a rebase.  

Also, a button to Abort a rebase would be good. Aborting a rebase is conceptually different from Discard, especially when autostash is in use.  Discard means to remove all working copy modifications, while rebase abort with autostash restores working copy modifications (to the state it was in before rebase was attempted)
fields.summary: Have rebase manipulation buttons available when git rebase conflict resolution is occuring.

fields.description:
!image-2018-03-16-22-22-36-767.png!

This "Please correct ..." warning is too aggressive.  It should not appear when I just opened this dialog and haven' t started typing in that "New Branch" text input area. Every time I open this dialog, I would first see the large red warning area and feel I cannot create branch for some reason, only to find out that I just need to start typing! This is very annoying and a waste of time. Please make it appear only if I started typing and deleted the area. Or make it display at that text input field with a gray color that isn' t so aggressive. Previous version didn' t have this.
fields.summary: The warning at New Branch dialog is too aggressive

fields.description: It would be nice if the pull window automatically selected the branch you are currently working off of when changing the remote source. Right now when you change the remote source it takes time to load the branches from that source, and then you have to manually select a branch after it loads.
fields.summary: Pull auto select branch when changing remote source

fields.description:
The [*german* site|https://de.atlassian.com/software/sourcetree] is displaying the wrong description on the 2 (read "two") BLUE buttons:

Current: "{color:#d04437}_Für *Mac OS X* herunterladen_{color}"

Should be: "{color:#14892c}Für *Windows* herunterladen{color}"

!2018-03-15 13_50_17-Sourcetree – Ein kostenloser Git- und Mercurial-Client _ Atlassian.png!

!2018-03-15 13_50_56-Sourcetree – Ein kostenloser Git- und Mercurial-Client _ Atlassian.png!
fields.summary: Wrong button description on web site

fields.description: When I want to create a pull request from branch context menu, I have to reenter the connection URL often. But I would expect to save it once for good at each repository. It is getting very annoying.
fields.summary: Pull request address gets deleted often.

fields.description: When I open log of file window, it's automatically maximized, but it looks like that's not done correctly. Icon for maximization in titlebar is not properly set, the borders of that window and of button Close are cut off etc. See attached screenshot.
fields.summary: File log window is maximized weird way when open

fields.description: After click on 'Jump to' and then on 'commit' at log-view the dialog should have focus to start typing immediately the commit-hash.
fields.summary: 'Log-View: Jump to -> Commit' should have focus to start typing

fields.description:
We would like to manage EUC-JP encoding files on Sourcetree.

The Sourcetree default character code set was UTF-8, so I changed it to EUC-JP.

After that diff line written in Japanese was displayed correctly on the diff pane (the right below pane).
 But on the commit list pane (the central pane), Sourcetree failed to show the commit message.
 The part of commit message wrtten in Japanese was broken.

 

Sourcetree is enable to show Japanese on each commit contents pane (the central below pane).
 Just commit list pane does not work correctly.
 It's strange.

 

I checked all the unresolved issues and I found some related issues, SRCTREEWIN-1048 and SRCTREEWIN-1474.
 But these tickets are still open for several years!

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Change the date setting of your computer to 和暦
## Select control panel
## Choose "Change date, time, or number formats"
## Select "Additional setings..."
## In the Date tab, select 和暦 from the Calendar type
# Open Sourcetree and view the previous commits in the branch

h3. Expected Results
The commit date will be 2018/MM/DD(or DD MM 2018)

h3. Actual Results
The commit date is 4006/MM/DD(or DD MM 4006)
 !スクリーンショット 2018-03-09 13.42.21.png|thumbnail!

Change Calendar type to English format(西暦)

fields.description:
Windows users often have to add .sh files, .py, and so on, which need the +x permission bit. The only known solution is to open Terminal and type in `git update-index --chmod=+x $FILE`

It would be a very big improvement, to add a right-click context menu, or even to create a git config option to do this automatically for filenames matching a pattern (such as `*.sh|*.py`).

fields.description:
My repos connected to bitbucket.org in sourcetree frequently get into a state where "push changes immediately to origin/master" starts flickering and becomes unusable without closing sourcetree and opening it again.   

It kind of feels like the software has been designed to do a denial of service after against bitbucket.org or gets in a infinite loop of some sort in recent versions.   With the bitbucket.org service being unavailable occasionally sometimes, It makes me wonder if the sourcetree client is the cause of this, since it seems to do tons of actions against bitbucket, which maybe should be reduced to a slower/controlled polling period and only for the currently active repo.  I'm just guessing on that, but it's definitely broken at least at the UI level.

Other bugs frequently observed:

The interface is often reporting wrong information for push/pull number. 

Often have to hit F5 to refresh views since the default refreshing is not good enough.

On another computer here, it is impossible to override the user you commit as on the global level, every repo has to be overridden.  Even after wiping out hidden files in appdata, it comes back somehow as the previous user.   I've reinstalled from scratch twice and can't figure it out.

The sourcetree program is able to crash instantly if you delete the .git folder for a repo that is already open.  Sometimes I clone and move them and this is annoying.  It should just close and mark it inaccessible instead of dying.

I've really tried to be patient for a release that fixes these issues, but it doesn't seem like it is coming so I'm reporting them myself.  I've seen at least 5 or 6 version upgrades yet the same problems persist.   We've been struggling with sourcetree bugs for at least 6 months.   I'm used to the new 2.0 layout now, but the bugs with common operations are very frustrating.  Sourcetree will be a good program whenever it gets stable again.
fields.summary: "push changes immediately to origin/master" flickering and unusable

In short, it's totally broken.  Refer to the screenshots attached.

Please fix this ASAP.

fields.description:
I have SourceTree configured with authentication information for Mercurial on Bitbucket and Git on Bitbucket, GitHub, and visualstudio.com . Recently, SourceTree will not authenticate correctly with GitHub. Although my GitHub credentials are saved in the SourceTree authentication settings, whenever I try to push to or pull from a GitHub repository, a "GitHub Login" window appears and asks me to enter my username and password. Even if I type the information correctly, SourceTree displays an error:

 
{noformat}
fatal: HttpRequestException encountered.
 An error occurred while sending the request.
remote: Invalid username or password.
{noformat}
 

However, I can log into GitHub using the same username and password in a browser. If I try to push or pull using the Git terminal, it shows the "{color:#333333}GitHub Login{color}" dialog and fails when I enter my information. Then it asks for a username in the terminal, then displays an OpenSSH password prompt. After I enter my password in the OpenSSH prompt, it does connect successfully. However, this approach only works in the terminal, and SourceTree does not detect changes made from the terminal - so if I push or pull, SourceTree doesn't realize it.

I have tried deleting my saved GitHub account information from SourceTree. I can remove GitHub from the sections "Accounts" and "Git Saved Paswords". However, once I remove GitHub from "Git Saved Passwords", it appears under "Rest Saved Passwords" and cannot be removed.

I've tried re-adding GitHub using both OAuth and Basic auth, and in both cases SourceTree reports "Authentication OK" from the settings dialog, but my issue persists - SourceTree always shows me the login prompt when I try to push or pull and always says that I typed in the password incorrectly even when I type it in correctly.

Again, I can log in through the browser or through Git terminal; I haven't forgotten my password and don't have trouble typing it in correctly.
fields.summary: SourceTree can't authenticate with Github

fields.description:
When SourceTree has multiple repos open as tabs, it can be a struggle to interact with the Commit button. I suspect this is because SourceTree will "wake up" and start polling the repos when you switch back to the tool. What this means though is that the time I switch to Sourcetree to do some work is the time that Sourcetree starts doing background work, and I am blocked.

Ideally I should be able to stage files and hit the commit button and have SourceTree add these actions to a queue so they can be completed when whatever background tasks are being run complete. This saves me from waiting for SourceTree to finish, or to compete with background tasks to interact with the UI.

fields.description:
*Short description of the bug:*
 When searching for a file and selecting it, it is possible that another file is selected in the background (hidden view), thus disabling single file operations in the right click.

*Steps to reproduce:*
 1. Go to Working Copy on the left panel
 2. From the top left drop down select "All files"
 3. In the Unstaged files, select one file
 4. On the top right panel, search for a file that doesn't match the file selected at step 3
 5. Select a file from the search result and right click it
 *Problem:* "Log Selected" and other options related to individual files are grayed out
 6. Clear the search and you will observe that both files selected (individually) at steps 3 and 5 are selected together

*Conclusion:*
 It seems that when making a search, the previous selection is still kept in the background (probably the non-matching files are hidden but their select attribute is not cleared).
 This means that when right clicking, you will see only options valid for a multiple file selection, even though in the view there is only one file selected.
fields.summary: Search in Working Copy - Files selected in background

fields.description: {color:#333333}Installed on Windows 7 from SourceTreeSetup-2.4.7.0.exe, Afterwards found no good way to start program as it doesn't make anything obvious in the Windows Start menu or any shortcut on the desktop.  I looked in various program files directory and did not find anything.  Googling led me to C:\Users[Username]\AppData\Local\Atlassian\SourceTree but it's not present there either.  I finally had to search my hard drive to find that the program is installed at C:\Users[Username]\AppData\Local\SourceTree and created my own shortcut to it.  Unclear if this is as designed.{color}

fields.description:
This appears to be a regression of SRCTREEWIN-4506.

Every second time I open SourceTree, I get the initial error
{code:java}
'ssh-agent' failed with code -1:

System.NullReferenceException: Object reference not set to an instance of an object.

()
{code}
Followed by several (about 3) of these errors:
{code:java}
'git tag' failed with code -1:

System.ComponentModel.Win32Exception: The system cannot find the file specified

(<path to my local repository>)
{code}
An equal number of errors which are idential except the command used is 'git status' not 'git tag'.

Attempting to load the branch view (by clicking the master branch) results in the same error for 'git log', and selecting the working copy again results in 'git tag' and 'git status' errors. Any action within SourceTree which would trigger an update of the relevant views causes the errors to be rethrown.

Restarting SourceTree works, as, like I mentioned, it only happens every second time SourceTree is opened (i.e. after a successfully started instance of the program is closed).

This affects versions going back quite a while, but I don't have specific version numbers. In the past it would crash on startup instead (still every second run), and the BugSplat reporter would open, this was fixed sometime in the last 6 months or so, I would estimate.
fields.summary: SourceTree unusable on startup ('ssh-agent' failed with code -1: System.NullReferenceException)

fields.description:
It is not possible to set up Windows SourceTree to connect to our Bitbucket Server. This is happening for all users who are creating accounts these days. Users are extremely frustrated, and our support (my team) is unable to help them because not only is it hard to figure out what is wrong, there also are no good web pages in Atlassian support that discuss the issue.

Version 2.4.7.0, after taking all the account and server info and the "Continue" button is clicked, does nothing after greying out the "Continue" button. No error message. No popup window. There is no way to know what is wrong. If you change any of the fields a little bit, you can try again, and the same plain old nothing will happen.

Not-too-old previous versions give an error "The hostname could not be parsed." Well, the URI works for my Mac and Linux versions of SourceTree, so Windows SourceTree is not telling the truth.

To complicate matters, if you skip account creation, selecting "clone in SourceTree" from a Bitbucket server repo's web page works fine. But that is not enough; we need the accounts to work properly too.

I've attached a short video showing the issue.
fields.summary: SourceTree for Win fails to connect to Bitbucket Server accounts

fields.description: We need to be able to install and use SourceTree without logging onto Atlassian. We have no no access to the internet. But we have millions of lines of code in a git hierarchy. SourceTree is one of the best git clients.
fields.summary: We need to install and use SourceTree in a closed environment with no internet access.

fields.description:
When viewing files in Tree View, right clicking a folder and selecting 'Show in Explorer', SourceTree will explorer.exe for each file in the folder.

 

This can lockup systems if the folder contains many items (eg. 1000).

 

This appears to happen because selecting a folder selects all the child items with its hierarchy. Ideally, if many files are selected for 'Show in Explorer' it only opens explorer.exe for unique folders.
fields.summary: 'Show in Explorer' will open explorer.exe for each file in folder

fields.description:
I am very surprised to not find this bug in the list as it has been happening since the release of the new UI.

The reproduction steps aren't exact but it happens all the time: 
 * Go to Commit 
 * Select a file to stage
 * Right click and press add
 * Things will go weird at this point and on the preview you'll start seeing  multiple previews
 * If you right click and add a different file, it will instead add every single file it's randomly previewing ( no folder is being chosen )

Now this in turn creates a number of other issues: 
 * If you right click and select show explorer, it will indefinitely start opening folders and windows will hung unless you force quit sourcetree and then all the Window's windows that have appeared.
 * Sometimes it selects files that are to be deleted or to be changed so the add option is greyed out
 * Can't easily see the preview of a single file since it's showing everything it randomly selected

If you click Stage Selected though it will only stage the correct file, even though the rest of the problems will persist

 

View all the problems in one screenshot:

https://www.dropbox.com/s/5zaneb7jb04690a/Screenshot%202018-02-10%2011.16.27.png?dl=0
fields.summary: During commit, sourcetree selects more files than the actual selected ones

fields.description:
Upon adding a GitHub hosting account and requesting a new OAuth token, SourceTree request way too much information which is not necessary at all to regular source control access and undermines the user's privacy.

Whereas the application would only need these accesses to operate normally:
** Repositories*Public and _private_

** Delete repositories*
 
It also requests access to many rights which have zero relevance to regular source control operation and are a direct violation of the user's privacy: 
* Personal user data (Full access)
** => Serious privacy issue there.
* Public SSH keys (Admin access)
** => How is this even relevant? 
* Repository webhooks and services (Admin access)
** => This is debatable, but administrative access is excessive.
* Organization webhooks (Admin access)
** => Cf previous point.
* Organizations and teams (Admin access)
** => Privacy issue again, and irrelevant to regular access.
* Notifications (Read access)
** => Debatable if SourceTree had support for these but it does not.
* Gists (Read and write access)
** => Why?

Please fix this and offer support by default for the *minimal* necessary amount of access, that is only access to repositories and nothing else.


And if you insist on requesting these rights, at least document explicitly why these are necessary (they aren't) and why you choose to harvest this data and level of access.
fields.summary: PRIVACY : GitHub OAuth authorization requires too broad access to user information

fields.description: Loading the changelog for older commits (file changes and diffs) has deteriorated significantly after 2.3.5 - switching revisions lists the individual files and diffs quite fast for ~10 minutes of uptime, after that diffs stop loading until application restart. Diffs for local uncommited changes are normally working OK, remote diffs are not loading.

how to disable the update options tab at all ?

(I will omit objections about that it is able to install version which is not officially provided neither referenced on sourcetree hoepage)

 

5/ how is this software meant to be used in enterprise companies where there are network access restrictions and policies for software installation ?

Thanks 
Commerzbank Aptech Team

fields.description:
Sourcetree appears to treat repos and subrepos separately.  Therefore pulls/pushes from them, which are all really actions on the main repo, can conflict with each other.  This is extremely problematic as a git status on the subrepo can cause a .lock file causing for instance a git rebase of the main repo to fail.

For subrepos, they really need to be treated as the repo that contains them when making calls to the git library or executable.  When any part of a repo with subrepos is busy, all parts of it are busy.

This is also able to have sourcetree put up it's processing blue bar, but I have now had that bar stay in excessive of 8 hours (pushed commit, went to bed) without ever completing.  This only occurs on repos with subrepos.  Only sourcetree is accessing files in that directory.  It's like a subrepo had a lock so the main repo enters waiting but since no main repo tasks were running it waits forever, since nothing tells it that it is done.

It is also possible to do a git pull in a subrepo and have it also lock forever, presumably because another subrepo or the main repo was doing some background refresh when the requested action started, so a lock was seen and it waits for the lock to go away but never gets notified when it does.

 

Repro steps is to create a repo with large subrepos.  We have binary assets in two subrepos so the main code repo is kept much smaller, but that means we have some huge subrepos.  Sourcetree's processing over the large number and size of files in the subrepo can be slow.  Multiple subrepos make this happen more.  We now have 4 subrepos.  Our other project with just 1 fails with .lock files or sometimes hangs as described here, but much less often.

 

Often when sourcetree gets confused, the only fix is to close sourcetree and reopen it.  And hope the action you need can be started on next opening before those background processes begin again.

 

Actions that seem to cause race conditions when using subrepos:
rebase
commit
checkout
fields.summary: SrcTree can soft lock when using subrepos
